Getting started

The MIDIv2 library grants MIDI functionality to AutoHotKey v2. All functions are conveniently wrapped in a single class.

This document contains descriptions and examples of all the properties and functions of the class.

To get started, place the MIDIv2.ahk in one of the script library paths. (See here for more info.)

Reference the library and create an instance of the class:

#Include <MIDIv2>
MIDI := MIDIv2()

From here, we are ready to open MIDI Input and Output ports for sending and receiving MIDI messages.

; Get the MIDI Out device ID from helper function
myOutputName := "MIDI Out"      ; Change this to the name of your MIDI Out port
myOutputID := GetOutputDeviceByName(myOutputName)
; Open the MIDI Out port
MIDI.OpenMidiOut(myOutputID)

; Send a Control Change message
; MIDI CC #7 (Volume), value 100, channel 5
MIDI.SendControlChange(7, 100, 5)

GetOutputDeviceByName(name) {
    outputDevices := MIDI.GetMidiOutDevices()
    Loop outputDevices.Length
        if outputDevices[A_Index] = name
            return A_Index - 1
    MsgBox("Output device: " name " is not available.")
    ExitApp
}

Note: Most of the following examples in this document will assume the library has been referenced and instantiated as above.

%break%

If the objective is to send or receive MIDI to/from applications running on the same computer as the AutoHotKey script, virtual MIDI ports will be required.

A robust and easy to use option is loopMIDI by Tobias Erichsen.  Create one port for incoming and another for outgoing MIDI data.

%break%

For more information about AutoHotKey, please see https://​www​.autohotkey​.com​/docs​/v2​/

%break%

Here is a working example of a simple one octave keyboard. The "+" and "-" keys are used to change the octave up or down respectively.

; One Octave Keyboard
; Use the computer keyboard to send Note On/Off messages
;Use the +/- keys to change octave

;  w e   t y u
; a s d f g h j k


#SingleInstance force
#Requires AutoHotkey >=2.0
#Include <MIDIv2>

; Create an instance of the MIDIv2 class
MIDI := MIDIv2()

; Get the MIDI Out device ID from helper function
myOutputName := "MIDI Out"      ; Change this to the name of your MIDI Out port
myOutputID := GetOutputDeviceByName(myOutputName)
; Open the MIDI Out port
MIDI.OpenMidiOut(myOutputID)

; Set default output MIDI channel to 2
MIDI.OutputChannel := 2

NOTES_IN_OCTAVE := 12
octave := 4

; Note On ----------------------------------------
q::
{
    Hotkey "q", "Off"    ; Prevent key repeat
    ; Send a Note On message with default velocity
    ; on the default MIDI Output channel
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(0 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
2::
{
    Hotkey "2", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(1 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
w::
{
    Hotkey "w", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(2 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
3::
{
    Hotkey "3", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(3 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
e::
{
    Hotkey "e", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(4 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
r::
{
    Hotkey "r", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(5 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
5::
{
    Hotkey "5", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(6 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
t::
{
    Hotkey "t", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(7 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
6::
{
    Hotkey "6", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(8 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
y::
{
    Hotkey "y", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(9 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
7::
{
    Hotkey "7", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(10 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
u::
{
    Hotkey "u", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(11 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
i::
{
    Hotkey "i", "Off"
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(1 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}

; Note Off ---------------------------------------
q Up::
{
    Hotkey "q", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(0 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
2 Up::
{
    Hotkey "2", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(1 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
w Up::
{
    Hotkey "w", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(2 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
3 Up::
{
    Hotkey "3", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(3 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
e Up::
{
    Hotkey "e", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(4 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
r Up::
{
    Hotkey "r", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(5 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
5 Up::
{
    Hotkey "5", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(6 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
t Up::
{
    Hotkey "t", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(7 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
6 Up::
{
    Hotkey "6", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(8 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
y Up::
{
    Hotkey "y", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(9 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
7 Up::
{
    Hotkey "7", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(10 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
u Up::
{
    Hotkey "u", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(11 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}
i Up::
{
    Hotkey "i", "On"
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(12 + octave * NOTES_IN_OCTAVE)
}

; Change octave ----------------------------------
+::
{
    Global octave
    octave++
}
-::
{
    Global octave
    octave--
}

GetOutputDeviceByName(name) {
    outputDevices := MIDI.GetMidiOutDevices()
    Loop outputDevices.Length
        if outputDevices[A_Index] = name
            return A_Index - 1
    MsgBox("Output device: " name " is not available.")
    ExitApp
}
Class Properties

Class properties are used to set default values as well as enable certain features that are by default turned off.

(Additional class properties are listed under the sections MMC & MTC and SRT.)

Properties
InputChannel

Set or Get a channel filter for the MIDI Input port

%dataType% int (Read/Write)

MIDIv2 will filter out incoming messages that are not equal to the InputChannel. Setting InputChannel to 0 allows input on all MIDI channels.

Valid range: 0-16. Default value is 0.

Example
MIDI.InputChannel := 8              ; Only allow messages on channel 8
myInputChannel := MIDI.InputChannel ; Retrieve the current input channel
OutputChannel

Set or Get a default output channel

%dataType% int (Read/Write)

Many functions that send MIDI messages, such as sendNoteOn or sendControlChange, have a MIDI Channel parameter as an optional argument.  If the MIDI Channel argument is not entered explicitly, the default output channel will be used.

Valid range: 1-16. Default is channel 1.

Example
MIDI.OutputChannel := 5
MIDI.SendNoteOn(80, 100, 1) ; Send Note On (80) with velocity 100 on MIDI channel 1
MIDI.SendNoteOn(80, 100)    ; Send Note On (80) with velocity 100 on MIDI channel 5
See Also

SendNoteOn

MidiThrough

Set or Get MIDI Through functionality

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

If enabled, the following MIDI messages arriving on the open Input Port will be automatically sent to the open Output Port:

  • Note On

  • Note Off

  • Control Change (including RPN/NRPN)

  • Program Change

  • Aftertouch

  • PitchBend

  • Poly Pressure

%break%

A MIDI Input port and a MIDI Output port needs to be open before enabling MIDI Through.

Example
MIDI.OpenMidiIn(3)
MIDI.OpenMidiOut(4)
MIDI.MidiThrough := True    ; Enable MIDI Through
See Also

OpenMidiIn, Receive MIDI, OpenMidiOut

CallbackPrefix

Set or Get a function name prefix for use in callback functions

%dataType% string (Read/Write)

Only one prefix can be used in a single class instance.  Default is "MidiIn".

Example
MsgBox(MIDI.callbackPrefix) ; Returns "MidiIn"
MIDI.CallbackPrefix := "MidiInputCallback_"
MidiInputCallback_NoteOn60(MidiEvent) {
    MsgBox("Note On 60`nVelocity: " MidiEvent.velocity)
}

Changes the callback function prefix from "MidiIn" to "MidiInputCallback_" and adds a callback for a Note On 60 event.

See Also

Receive MIDI, NoteOn

RPN_Enabled

Set or Get support for RPN callbacks.

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

Adding support for RPN callbacks tells MIDIv2 to interpret a set of 4 incoming Control Change messages as a single event.

When RPN_Enabled is set to True, ControlChange callbacks for Control number 6, 38, 100 and 101 will not fire.

Example
MIDI.RPN_Enabled := True
See Also

RPN

NRPN_Enabled

Set or Get support for NRPN callbacks.

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

Adding support for NRPN callbacks tells MIDIv2 to interpret a set of 4 incoming Control Change messages as a single event.

When NRPN_Enabled is set to True, ControlChange callbacks for Control number 6, 38, 98 and 99 will not fire.

Example
MIDI.NRPN_Enabled := True
See Also

NRPN

SysExInputBuffers

Set or Get the number of buffers used to receive SysEx data.

%dataType% int (Read/Write)

Defining the number of buffers can be done before or after a MIDI Input port has been opened.

Example
; Use 64 input buffers, each with a size of 1KB
; Total buffer capacity: 64KB (65536 Bytes)
MIDI.SysExInputBuffers := 64
MIDI.SysExInputBufferSize := 1024   ;1KB
See Also

SysExInputBufferSize

SysExInputBufferSize

Set or Get the size of each buffer used to receive SysEx data.

%dataType% int (Read/Write)

Defining the size of the buffers can be done before or after a MIDI Input port has been opened.

Example
; Use 16 input buffers, each with a size of 32KB
; Total buffer capacity: 512KB (524288 Bytes)
MIDI.SysExInputBuffers := 16
MIDI.SysExInputBufferSize := 32768  ;32KB
See Also

SysExInputBuffers

MIDI Ports

A set of functions for opening, closing and retrieving available MIDI ports.

Functions
GetMidiInDevices
GetMidiInDevices()

Retrieves all available MIDI input ports

The result is returned in an array where the first array element corresponds to Device ID 0, the second to Device ID 1 and so on.

Parameters

None

Returns

A String array of all available MIDI input ports

Example
; List all available MIDI Input Ports
midiInDevices := MIDI.GetMidiInDevices()
Loop midiInDevices.Length
    allInDevices .= A_Index - 1 " - " midiInDevices[A_Index] "`n"
MsgBox("MIDI IN:`n" allInDevices)
; Find the Device ID of a specific MIDI Input Port
GetInputDeviceByName(name) {
    inputDevices := MIDI.GetMidiInDevices()
    Loop inputDevices.Length
        if inputDevices[A_Index] = name
            return A_Index - 1
    MsgBox("Input device: " name " is not available.")
    ExitApp
}
GetMidiOutDevices
GetMidiOutDevices()

Retrieves all available MIDI output ports

The result is returned in an array where the first array element corresponds to Device ID 0, the second to Device ID 1 and so on.

Parameters

None

Returns

A String array of all available MIDI output ports

Example
; List all available MIDI Output Ports
midiOutDevices := MIDI.GetMidiOutDevices()
loop midiOutDevices.Length
    allOutDevices .= A_Index - 1 " - " midiOutDevices[A_Index] "`n"
MsgBox("MIDI OUT:`n" allOutDevices)
; Find the Device ID of a specific MIDI Output Port
GetOutputDeviceByName(name) {
    outputDevices := MIDI.GetMidiOutDevices()
    Loop outputDevices.Length
        if outputDevices[A_Index] = name
            return A_Index - 1
    MsgBox("Output device: " name " is not available.")
    ExitApp
}
OpenMidiOut
OpenMidiOut(
int 
devID
)

Opens an available MIDI port for sending messages.

Only one output port can be opened per class instance. The first port available has an ID number of 0.

You can use GetMidiOutDevices to retrieve the device names.

Parameters
devID
int

Unique ID number of the MIDI output port

Example
; Open an output port with ID number 4
MIDI.OpenMidiOut(4)
CloseMidiOut
CloseMidiOut()

Closes an open output port. If an output port is not open, CloseMidiOut has no effect.

Parameters

None

OpenMidiIn
OpenMidiIn(
int 
devID
)

Opens an available MIDI port for receiving messages.

Only one input port can be opened per class instance. The first port available has an ID number of 0.

You can use getMidiInDevices to retrieve the device names.

Parameters
devID
int

Unique ID number of the MIDI input port

Example
; Open an input port with ID number 6
MIDI.OpenMidiIn(6)
CloseMidiIn
CloseMidiIn()

Closes an open input port. If an input port is not open, CloseMidiIn has no effect.

Parameters

None

Send MIDI
Functions
SendNoteOn
SendNoteOn(
int 
noteValue,
int 
velocity,
int 
channel
)

Send a Note On message with an optional Velocity value and MIDI Channel

Parameters
noteValue
int

0-127

velocity
int

0-127

Optional. Default value is 127.

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Ctrl + q
^q::
{
    ; Send a A7 (105) Note On message with
    ; velocity 100 on channel 8
    MIDI.SendNoteOn(105, 100, 8)
}
; Send a C2 (36) Note On message with
; velocity 48 on the default MIDI Out channel
MIDI.SendNoteOn(45, 48)

; Send a F5 (77) Note Off message with
; default velocity (127) on the default MIDI Out channel
MIDI.SendNoteOn(45)
SendNoteOff
SendNoteOff(
int 
noteValue,
int 
velocity,
int 
channel
)

Send a Note Off message with an optional Velocity value and MIDI Channel

Parameters
noteValue
int

0-127

velocity
int

0-127

Optional. Default value is 64.

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send a C#4 (61) Note Off message
; with velocity 100 on channel 2
MIDI.SendNoteOff(61, 100, 2)

; Send a A2 (45) Note Off message with
; velocity 20 on the default MIDI Out channel
MIDI.SendNoteOff(45, 20)

; Send Note Off messages on all notes with
; default velocity (64) on the default MIDI Out channel
Loop 128 {
    MIDI.SendNoteOff(A_Index - 1)
}
SendPolyPressure
SendPolyPressure(
int 
noteValue,
int 
value,
int 
channel
)

Send Poly Pressure (polyphonic aftertouch) on a specific MIDI note

Parameters
noteValue
int

0-127

value
int

0-127, Poly Pressure value

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send Poly Pressure on note G3 (55)
; with a pressure value of 90
; on channel 6
MIDI.SendNoteOn(55, 90, 6)
SendControlChange
SendControlChange(
int 
controller,
int 
value,
int 
channel
)

Send a Control Change (MIDI CC) message

Parameters
number

0-127, Controller number

value
int

0-127, Controller value

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send MIDI CC#1 (Modulation)
; with a value of 30
; on the default output channel
MIDI.SendControlChange(1, 30)
SendControlChangePair
SendControlChangePair(
int 
controller,
int 
value,
int 
channel
)

Send a 14-bit Control Change (MIDI CC) message

This functions takes a 14-bit value, internally splits it up into an MSB and LSB part and sends it as two separate Control Change messages.

The controller parameter represents the MSB of the value pair. The corresponding LSB message is automatically generated and sent with the controller number + 32.

For example, specifying a controller number of 8 will send the MSB part of the value as a CC #8 message and the LSB part of the value as a CC #40 message.

%break%

SendControlChangePair can potentially be used in conjunction with SendRPN or SendNRPN if the receiving device supports it. In those cases, use a controller value of 6 to specify Data Entry MSB/LSB.

Parameters
controller
int

0-31, controller number (MSB)

value
int

0-16383, controller value

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send 14-bit value on MIDI CC #11 (MSB) and #43 (LSB)
; (14-bit Expression Controller)

value14bit := 2325
MIDI.SendControlChangePair(11, value14bit)

; Equivalent to writing two separate SendControlChange() instructions:
; SendControlChange(11, 18) ;MSB
; SendControlChange(43, 21) ;LSB
; Send Data Entry of NRPN message

NRPN_Parameter := 270
MIDI.SendNRPN(NRPN_Parameter, 8192) ;Establish the NRPN Parameter and initial value
MIDI.SendControlChangePair(6, 8320) ;Send new NRPN value (Data Entry)
See Also

SendControlChange, SendRPN, SendNRPN

SendProgramChange
SendProgramChange(
int

)

Send Pitchbend

Parameters

0-16383, Pitch bend

channel

Example
; Send Pitchbend
; with a value of 8192 (center position)
; on the default output channel
MIDI.SendPitchbend(8192)
SendRPN
SendRPN(
int 
parameter,
int 
value,
int 
channel
)

Send MIDI RPN (Registered Parameter Number)

A Registered Parameter Number message is composed of 4 separate MIDI CC messages divided up into Parameter Number and Data Value.

Both ~Parameter Number~ and ~Data Value~ are defined as 14-bit integers and sent as separate MSB and LSB messages.

  • MIDI CC #101 = Parameter Value MSB

  • MIDI CC #100 = Parameter Value LSB

  • MIDI CC #06 = Data Value MSB

  • MIDI CC #38 = Data Value LSB

%break%

The SendRPN function handles sending each part and the user only need to supply the Parameter Number and Data Value as two 14-bit integers.

The MIDI v1.0 specification pre-defines a number of RPN messages and discourages the use of RPN for custom data.  Custom parameters should use NRPN (SendNRPN) instead.

Parameters
parameter
int

0-16383, Parameter Value

value
int

0-16383, Data Value

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send Fine Tuning as RPN
; 0 cents from A440
ParameterNumber := 1
DataValue := 8192
MIDI.SendRPN(ParameterNumber, DataValue)
See Also

SendControlChange, SendControlChangePair

SendNRPN
SendNRPN(
int 
parameter,
int 
value,
int 
channel
)

Send MIDI NRPN (Non Registered Parameter Number)

A Non-Registered Parameter Number message is composed of 4 separate MIDI CC messages divided up into Parameter Number and Data Value.

Both ~Parameter Number~ and ~Data Value~ are defined as 14-bit integers and sent as separate MSB and LSB messages.

  • MIDI CC #99 = Parameter Value MSB

  • MIDI CC #98 = Parameter Value LSB

  • MIDI CC #06 = Data Value MSB

  • MIDI CC #38 = Data Value LSB

%break%

The SendNRPN function handles sending each part and the user only need to supply the Parameter Number and Data Value as two 14-bit integers.

Parameters
parameter
int

0-16383, Parameter Value

value
int

0-16383, Data Value

channel
int

1-16

Optional. Default value, see OutputChannel

Example
; Send NRPN (on default MIDI Channel)
ParameterNumber := 1500
DataValue := 12500
MIDI.SendNRPN(ParameterNumber, DataValue)
See Also

SendControlChange

SysEx

SysEx messages (LongData messages) can be sent and received using MIDIv2.

Incoming and outgoing SysEx messages are buffered and each buffer has a maximum size of 64KB (65536 Bytes). (The MIDI device driver might limit this size further.)

The size of and number of buffers used to receive SysEx data is user definable via two class properties, SysExInputBuffers and SysExInputBufferSize.  If a SysEx message is sent to a MIDI Input port opened with MIDIv2 that exceeds the total size of the SysEx Input buffers, an error message is shown and the entire SysEx message is discarded.

Each message requires a start byte of 0xF0 and an end byte of 0xF7. Each byte in between the start and end byte is limited to 7 bits.

In addition to sending and receiving SysEx messages, the MIDIv2 class also offers a few functions for converting data to and from the SysEx format.

SysEx messages are sent as a space delimited string of hexadecimals.

SysExMessage := "F0 48 65 6C 6C 6F 20 77 6F 72 6C 64 21 F7"

For more information about SysEx messages, see https://​midi​.org​/midi-1-0-universal-system-exclusive​-messages

Functions
SendSysEx
SendSysEx(
string 
sysExString
)
Parameters
sysexString
string

Full SysEx message

Example
; Construct the SysEx message
SysExMessage := "F0 48 65 6C 6C 6F 20 77 6F 72 6C 64 21 F7"
; Send message
MIDI.SendSysEx(SysExMessage)
ArrayHexToSysEx
ArrayHexToSysEx(
string 
arr[]
)

Converts an array of hexadecimal numbers to a SysEx string

Parameters
arr
string[]

Array of string. Each element formatted as a hexadecimal number.

Returns

A string formatted as a SysEx message. Hexadecimal, space delimited.

Example
; Array of hexadecimal numbers
SysExArray := ["F0", "48", "65", "6C", "6C", "6F", "20", "77", "6F", "72", "6C", "64", "21", "F7"]

; Convert array
SysExMessage := MIDI.ArrayHexToSysEx(SysExArray)    ; Returns: "F0 48 65 6C 6C 6F 20 77 6F 72 6C 64 21 F7"

; Send message
MIDI.SendSysEx(SysExMessage)
ArrayDecToSysEx
ArrayDecToSysEx(
int 
arr[]
)

Converts an array of decimal numbers to a SysEx string

Parameters
arr
int[]

Array of integers. Each element formatted as a hexadecimal number.

Returns

A string formatted as a SysEx message. Hexadecimal, space delimited.

Example
; Array of decimal numbers
SysExArray := [240, 72, 101, 108, 108, 111, 247]

; Convert array
SysExMessage := MIDI.ArrayDecToSysEx(SysExArray)    ; Returns: "F0 48 65 6C 6C 6F F7"

; Send message
MIDI.SendSysEx(SysExMessage)
TextToSysEx
TextToSysEx(
string 
str
)

Converts an ASCII encoded text string to a SysEx format

Note that only the first 127 ASCII characters are permitted.

If a larger character map is required, such as ANSI or UTF-8, custom SysEx messages will have to be composed manually.

Parameters
str
string

Text string

Returns

A string formatted as a SysEx message. Hexadecimal, space delimited.

(Start and end bytes (0xF0 and 0xF7) are not automatically added.)

Example
myText := "Hello there!"
; Convert to SysEx
SysExMessage := "F0 " MIDI.TextToSysEx(myText) " F7"
See Also

SendSysEx

SysExToText
SysExToText(
string 
sysEx
)

Converts a SysEx message to an ASCII encoded text string

Note that each byte in the SysEx message is interpreted as a 7-bit ASCII character.  If a larger character map is required, such as ANSI or UTF-8, custom SysEx messages will have to be interpreted manually.

Parameters
sysEx
string

SysEx message

Returns

An ASCII encoded string.  The start and end bytes of 0xF0 and 0xF7 respectively are ignored if present.

Example
MidiInSysEx(sysExEvent) {
    txt := MIDI.SysExToString(SysExEvent.string)
    MsgBox("SysEx message (string):`n" . txt)
}
See Also

SysEx(SysExEvent)

Receive MIDI

How to receive MIDI with MIDIv2.

When a MIDI message is received by the port opened with OpenMidiIn, an event is raised and a corresponding callback function is attempted to be called.

The event handlers are automatically managed by the MIDIv2 class,\ but users need to define their own callback function to handle a specific MIDI event.  For example, create a function named %code%MidiInNoteOn(midiEvent)%/code% to handle ~Note On~ messages.

The naming convention for these callback functions combines the user-defined CallbackPrefix parameter with the MIDI message type.  If CallbackPrefix is not specified, the default prefix is "MidiIn".

MIDI message types

  • NoteOn¹

  • NoteOff¹

  • PolyPressure¹

  • ControlChange¹

  • ProgramChange

  • Aftertouch

  • Pitchbend

  • RPN

  • NRPN

  • SysEx

%break%

¹ These types can be optionally defined with a number directly following the type.

For example ControlChange will trigger on any Control number whereas ControlChange7 will only trigger on Control number 7 (Volume).

%break%

Callbacks for all above MIDI message types must be defined with one argument.  This argument is an object with properties relevant to the specific MIDI message received.

Callbacks

Short message callbacks and SysEx callbacks.

(Additional callbacks are listed under the sections MMC & MTC and SRT.)

NoteOn[n]
NoteOn[n](
midiEvent
)

MIDI Note On message

An incoming Note On message has two types of callbacks. One for the specific note value and one for all Note On messages.

midiEvent
EventType

Equal to "NoteOn"

Channel

(1-16) MIDI channel the event is received on

NoteNumber

(0-127) MIDI Note number

Velocity

(0-127) Note On velocity

Example
; Default prefix is "MidiIn"
MidiInNoteOn55(midiEvent) {
    MsgBox("G5 Note On triggered!")
}

; Capture all Note On events
MidiInNoteOn(midiEvent) {
    note := midiEvent.NoteNumber
    velocity := midiEvent.Velocity
    channel := midiEvent.Channel
    MsgBox("NOTE ON`nNote: " note "`nVelocity: " velocity "`nChannel: " channel)
}
NoteOff[n]
NoteOff[n](
midiEvent
)

MIDI Note Off message

An incoming Note Off message has two types of callbacks. One for the specific note value and one for all Note Off messages.

midiEvent
EventType

Equal to "NoteOff"

Channel

(1-16) MIDI channel the event is received on

NoteNumber

(0-127) MIDI Note number

Velocity

(0-127) Note Off velocity

PolyPressure[n]
PolyPressure[n](
midiEvent
)

MIDI Poly Pressure message

An incoming Poly Pressure message has two types of callbacks. One for the specific note number and one for all Poly Pressure messages.

midiEvent
EventType

Equal to "PolyPressure"

Channel

(1-16) MIDI channel the event is received on

NoteNumber

(0-127) MIDI Note number

Pressure

(0-127) Pressure Value

Example
; Receive Poly Pressure for middle C (note #60)
MidiInPolyPressure60(midiEvent) {
    msg := "Poly Pressure on C4 is: " midiEvent.Pressure
    msg .= "`nMessage received on channel: " midiEvent.Channel
    MsgBox(msg)
}

Controller

(0-127) Controller Number

Value

(0-127) Controller Value

Example
; Receive Modulation Wheel message

    MsgBox("Mod Wheel value is: " midiEvent.Value)
}

}
RPN
RPN(
midiEvent
)

MIDI RPN message

Requires the RPN_Enabled parameter to be set to "True".

When Control Change messages with the following control numbers are received by MIDIv2, a single RPN event is raised and can captured using the RPN callback:

  • 101 (Registered Parameter Number MSB)

  • 100 (Registered Parameter Number LSB)

  • 6 (Data Entry MSB)

  • 38 (Data Entry LSB)

The order of these incoming MIDI Control Change messages do not matter.

Once a full Parameter number and Value (Data Entry) has been received, any subsequent incoming Control Change message pairs, on the same MIDI Channel, with Control number 6 and 38 will be treated as a new NRPN event with the same Parameter number as the one last received.

midiEvent
EventType

Equal to "RPN"

Channel

(1-16) MIDI channel the event is received on

Parameter

(0-16383) 14-bit Parameter number

Value

(0-16383) 14-bit Data Entry

Example
MidiInRPN(midiEvent) {
    MsgBox(
        "Type=" midiEvent.EventType
        "`nParameter=" midiEvent.Parameter
        "`nValue=" midiEvent.Value
    )
}
See Also

RPN_Enabled, SendControlChangePair

NRPN
NRPN(
midiEvent
)

MIDI NRPN message

Requires the NRPN_Enabled parameter to be set to "True".

When Control Change messages with the following control numbers are received by MIDIv2, a single NRPN event is raised and can captured using the NRPN callback:

  • 99 (Non-Registered Parameter Number MSB)

  • 98 (Non-Registered Parameter Number LSB)

  • 6 (Data Entry MSB)

  • 38 (Data Entry LSB)

The order of these incoming MIDI Control Change messages do not matter.

Once a full Parameter number and Value (Data Entry) has been received, any subsequent incoming Control Change message pairs, on the same MIDI Channel, with Control number 6 and 38 will be treated as a new NRPN event with the same Parameter number as the one last received.

midiEvent
EventType

Equal to "NRPN"

Channel

(1-16) MIDI channel the event is received on

Parameter

(0-16383) 14-bit Parameter number

Value

(0-16383) 14-bit Data Entry

Example
MidiInNRPN(midiEvent) {
    MsgBox(
        "Type=" midiEvent.EventType
        "`nParameter=" midiEvent.Parameter
        "`nValue=" midiEvent.Value
    )
}
See Also

NRPN_Enabled, SendControlChangePair

SysEx
SysEx(
sysExEvent
)

MIDI SysEx messages

sysExEvent
ArrHex

Array of each SysEx byte formatted as hexadecimal string

(First element is "F0" and the last is "F7")

ArrDec

Array of each SysEx byte formatted as decimal integer

String

SysEx message as a single string, space delimited

Size

Total number of bytes in the message

Example
MidiInSysEx(sysExEvent) {
    ; Convert message to text
    SysEx_Text := MIDI.SysExToText(sysExEvent.String)
    MsgBox("SysEx message:`n" . SysEx_Text)
}
MidiInSysEx(sysExEvent) {
    ; Act on specific bytes within the message
    For _, hex in sysExEvent.ArrHex {
        Switch hex, 0 {
            Case "30":
                ; 0x30
            Case "3A":
                ; 0x3A
            Case "F0", "F7":
                ; SysEx start/end byte
        }
    }
}
MidiInSysEx(sysExEvent) {
    MsgBox("Fist message byte: " . sysExEvent.Array[2])

    SysEx_Size := sysExEvent.Size ; Number of bytes in the message
    MsgBox("Last message byte: " . sysExEvent.array[SysEx_Size - 1])
}
See Also

SysExToText

MMC & MTC

MIDI Machine Control and MIDI Time Code

MIDIv2 comes with predefined functions and callbacks for basic MIDI Machine Control, Machine Control Response and MIDI Time Code.  Some commands (MCS, MCP) have been excluded from MIDIv2 due to being specialty and/or legacy.  For more advanced handling of MMC or MTC, messages can always be manually created and sent with the sendSysEx function and responses can be received via the SysEx(sysExEvent) callback.

By default, MCR (Machine Control Response) and MTC callbacks are disabled and must be enabled with the class properties MMC_Enabled and/or TC_Enabled.

%break%

For more information about MMC, see the MIDI Machine Control Specification document available for download at https://​midi​.org

Properties
MMC_Enabled

Set or get support for Machine Control callbacks.

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

Example
MIDI.MMC_Enabled := True
See Also

Callbacks [2]

TC_Enabled

Set or get support for Time Code callbacks.

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

Example
MIDI.TC_Enabled := True
See Also

Callbacks [2]

MMC_deviceID

Set or Get the Device ID used to send and receive MMC/MCR data

%dataType% int (Read/Write)

Device ID is the communication address used to send and receive MMC/MCR data.  A value of 1-126 denotes a single, unique ID whereas 127 (0x7F) is used to send and receive to all devices.  Default value is 127 (0x7F). The partner device must be set to the same ID unless 0x7F is used.

Example
; Set Device ID to a single "channel" (32)
MIDI.MMC_DeviceID := 0x20
Functions
MMC_Stop
MMC_Stop()

Change MCS (Motion Control State) to Stop

Instruct the receiving device to stop. Stops Play, Record, FastForward and Rewind.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + NumpadDot = Stop
+^NumpadDot::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Stop()
}
MMC_Play
MMC_Play()

Change MCS (Motion Control State) to Play

Instruct the receiving device to start playing.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + NumEnter = Play
+^NumpadEnter::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Play()
}
MMC_DPlay
MMC_DPlay()

Change MCS (Motion Control State) to Deferred Play

This command is almost identical to MMC_Play with the exception that if the target device is in the process of locating. Play will then start when locate is completed.

Parameters

None

See Also

MMC_Play, MMC_Locate

MMC_FF
MMC_FF()

Change MCS to Fast Forward

Instruct the receiving device to fast forward. The device will fast forward until a stop command is received.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + NumpadPlus = FF
+^NumpadAdd::
{
    MIDI.MMC_FF()
    Hotkey "+^NumpadAdd", "Off"    ; Prevent key repeat
}
+^NumpadAdd Up::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Stop()
    Hotkey "+^NumpadAdd", "On"
}
MMC_Rewind
MMC_Rewind()

Change MCS to Rewind

Instruct the receiving device to rewind. The device will rewind until a stop command is received.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + NumpadMinus = FF
+^NumpadSub::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Rewind()
    Hotkey "+^NumpadSub", "Off"    ; Prevent key repeat
}
+^NumpadSub Up::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Stop()
    Hotkey "+^NumpadSub", "On"
}
MMC_Record
MMC_Record()

Change MCS to Record Strobe

Instruct the receiving device to start recording on all record enabled tracks.

If the target device is in Stop state, upon receiving this command it should start recording right away (Record+Play).  This command can also be sent if the target device is already in a Play state upon which it will act as a Punch In command.

If the target device already is in a Record state, upon receiving this command recording will cease and the device will continue in a Play state—effectively acting as a Punch Out command.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + NumpadMultiply = FF
+^NumpadMult::
{
    MIDI.MMC_Record()
}
MMC_RecordExit
MMC_RecordExit()

End recording on all recording tracks

Effectively a Punch Out command. The target device will switch from record to play.

Parameters

None

See Also

MMC_Record

MMC_RecordPause
MMC_RecordPause()

Set target device to a ready-to-record state

This command requires that a MMC_Pause command was send beforehand. If the target device is not in a MCS Pause state, this command should be ignored.

Parameters

None

See Also

MMC_Record, MMC_Pause

MMC_Pause
MMC_Pause()

Instruct the target device to stop as soon as possible

Similar to MMC_RecordPause, this command should set the target device in a state that minimizes the time to reach a Play state.

If the target device is in a Recording state when it receives a Pause command, it should enter a Record-Pause state.

Parameters

None

See Also

MMC_Play, MMC_RecordPause

MMC_Locate
MMC_Locate(
string or 
int[] 
timeCode
)

Locate to new Time Code

Set a Time Code value and initiate the MCP (Motion Control Process) command Locate.

The single argument can be sent either as a string or as an array of int. The Time code format is: %code%"hh:mm:ss:ff"%/code%

where:

hh

Hours - 2 digits (00-23)

mm

Minutes - 2 digits (00-59)

ss

Seconds - 2 digits (00-59)

ff

Frames - 2 digits (00-30)¹

¹The max value for Frames depends on the FPS setting of the target device

Parameters
timeCode
string or int[]

Time Code to move to

Example
; Using a string value
TC_String := "00:02:44:20"
MIDI.MMC_Locate(TC_String)

; Using an array
TC_Array := [0, 2, 44, 20]
MIDI.MMC_Locate(TC_Array)
MMC_RequestTimeCode
MMC_RequestTimeCode()

Request current Time Code and Frame Rate

The response from the target device will trigger the TC_RunningFull callback function.

Parameters

None

See Also

<TCFull>

Callbacks [2]

MMC & MTC Callbacks

For more information about receiving MIDI, see Receive MIDI.

TC_Full
TC_Full(
timeCode
)

Receive current Time Code

This message is typically sent when the device enters a Stop state or after a locating.

It can also be sent as a response to receiving the MMC_requestTimeCode command.

timeCode
hours

(0-23)

minutes

(0-59)

seconds

(0-59)

frames

(0-30)¹

frameRateCode

(0-3)²

frameRate

One of the 4 frame rates as a float number

¹The max value for Frames depends on the FPS setting of the target device

²Frame rate codes are:

0 = 24 FPS

1 = 25 FPS

2 = 29.97 FPS (or 30 FPS Drop Frame)

3 = 30 FPS

Example
MidiInTCFull(timeCode) {
    ; Create a TC string
    TCString := Format(":02i", timeCode.hours) . ":"
    TCString .= Format(":02i", timeCode.minutes) . ":"
    TCString .= Format(":02i", timeCode.seconds) . ":"
    TCString .= Format(":02i", timeCode.frames)

    MsgBox("Time Code:`n" . TCString . "`nFrame rate:`n" . timeCode.frameRate)
}
MCR_Stop
MCR_Stop()

Current Motion Control State (MCS) is Stop

This MCR (Machine Control Response) is the first of several response messages that annouce the target device's control state.

This and the following state callbacks are triggered whenever the device's status changes, be it remotely or localy.

Parameters

None

Parameters

MCR_RecordOff
MCR_RecordOff()

Record Mode is off

Indicates that the target device has stopped recording

See Also

MCR_RecordOn, MMC_Record, MMC_RecordExit

Indicates that the target device has started recording

MMC_SysEx
MMC_SysEx(
sysExEvent
)

Machine Control Response or State in a SysEx object

This event is raised whenever a MMC or MTC related message is received as a SysEx message.

In MIDIv2, it includes all MMC and TC related messages with the exception of running Time Code messages (TC_RunningFull).

It includes all SysEx messages that begin with %code%"F0 F7"%/code%.

This event can be used to capture any states or procedures not already covered by the above callbacks.

The MCC_SysEx callback is triggered even if a callback for a specific MCC/TC event is defined.

MCC_SysEx requires the class parameters MMC_Enabled and/or TC_Enabled to be true.

sysExEvent
ArrHex

Array of each SysEx byte formatted as hexadecimal

(First element is "F0" and the last is "F7")

ArrDec

Array of each SysEx byte formatted as decimal integer

String

SysEx message as one string, space delimited

Size

Total number of bytes in the message

See Also

SysEx

TC_RunningFull
TC_RunningFull(
MidiEvent
)

Time Code from running transport

This callback is triggered when the transport of the target device is running in either a Play or Record state.

When the device is running, it send out a partial time code message once every quarter frame. Each message contains 4 bits of Time Code data and it takes 8 of these messages to create a full Time Code value.  As such, TC_RunningFull is triggered once every 2nd frame.

MidiEvent
Hours

(0-23)

Minutes

(0-59)

Seconds

(0-59)

Frames

(0-30)¹

FrameRateCode

(0-3)²

FrameRate

One of the 4 frame rates as a float number

¹The max value for frames depends on the FPS setting of the target device

²Frame rate codes are:

0 = 24 FPS

1 = 25 FPS

2 = 29.97 FPS (or 30 FPS Drop Frame)

3 = 30 FPS

See Also

SysEx

SRT

System Real Time messages

System Real Time messages are used to synchronize receiving MIDI devices to a clock pulse signal, sometimes referred to as "MIDI Clock" or "MIDI Beat Clock".  The sync pulse rate is defined as 24 pulses per quarter note and the device generating the clock signals can typically be configured to send the pulses continuously or only during "Play state".

In addition to the clock pulse messages (SRT_TimingClock), SRT also define messages for Start, Continue, Stop, Active Sensing and System Reset.

MIDIv2 supports sending and receiving all above mentioned SRT messages via predefined functions and callbacks.

By default, SRT (System Real Time) callbacks are disabled and must be enabled with the class property SRT_Enabled.

%break%

For more information about System Real Time, see the MIDI 1.0 DETAILED SPECIFICATION document available for download at https://​midi​.org

Properties
SRT_Enabled

Set or get support for System Real Time callbacks.

%dataType% bool (Read/Write)

Example
MIDI.SRT_Enabled := True
See Also

Callbacks [3]

Functions
SRT_TimingClock
SRT_TimingClock()

System Real Time clock pulse

Clock pulse signal defined at 24 ppqn (pulses per quarter note).

%break%

Note: Accurate timing loops in AutoHotKey are difficult to realize. Relying on an AutoHotKey script alone as a stable clock source is not recommended.

Parameters

None

SRT_Start
SRT_Start()

System Real Time Start command

Instruct receiving device(s) to start synchronization at beginning of song/sequence at the next received clock pulse.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + Numpad0 = Start
+^Numpad0::
{
    MIDI.SRT_Start()
}
SRT_Continue
SRT_Continue()

System Real Time Continue command

Instruct receiving device(s) to continue synchronization from its current location at the next received clock pulse.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + Numpad1 = Continue
+^Numpad1::
{
    MIDI.SRT_Continue()
}
SRT_Stop
SRT_Stop()

System Real Time Stop command

Command the synchronized device(s) to stop playback.

Parameters

None

Example
; Ctrl + Shift + Numpad2 = Stop
+^Numpad2::
{
    MIDI.SRT_Stop()
}
SRT_ActiveSensing
SRT_ActiveSensing()

System Real Time Active Sensing

Active Sensing is an optional mechanism to ensure a transmitting device is "alive" and connected.

When a receiving device is sent an Active Sensing message it should expect to receive some kind of MIDI message to arrive within 300ms intervals. The Active Sensing message is used only when no other messages are being transmitted within that window.  If a receiving device is not sent a MIDI message, Active Sensing or other, within the 300ms window, it is assumed the connection is lost.

Parameters

None

Example
class ActiveSensingTimer {
    __New() {
        this.interval := 270    ; Use 270ms to accommodate timing inaccuracies
        this.timer := ObjBindMethod(this, "_AS")
    }

    Start() {
        SetTimer this.timer, this.interval
    }

    Stop() {
        SetTimer this.timer, 0
    }

    _AS() {
        MIDI.SRT_ActiveSensing()
    }
}
SRT_SystemReset
SRT_SystemReset()

System Real Time System Reset command

Tell receiving devices to initialize to a power-up state.

The MIDI v1.0 specification defines these actions to be taken upon receiving a System Reset command:

%numList%

  • Set Omni On, Poly mode (if implemented)

  • Set Local On

  • Turn Voices Off

  • Reset all controllers

  • Set Song Position to 0

  • Stop playback

  • Clear Running Status

  • Reset the instrument to its power-up condition

%/numList%

Parameters

None

Callbacks [3]

System Real Time event callbacks

For more information about receiving MIDI, see Receive MIDI.

SRT_TimingClock
SRT_TimingClock()

System Real Time 24 ppqn sync message

Use this callback to capture MIDI Clock sync messages. The clock source should generate 24 Timing Clock messages every quarter note (1/64T note length value).

Example
ppqn := 1
MidiInSRT_TimingClock() {
    Global ppqn
    if Mod(ppqn, 96) = 1 {
        ; 1/1 pulse
    }
    if Mod(ppqn, 48) = 1 {
        ; 1/2 pulse
    }
    if Mod(ppqn, 24) = 1 {
        ; 1/4 pulse
    }
    if Mod(ppqn, 12) = 1 {
        ; 1/8 pulse
    }

    ppqn := (ppqn = 96) ? 1 : ppqn += 1
}
SRT_Start
SRT_Start()

System Real Time Start command

This SRT command is sent by the clock source to tell the receiving device it should start playing from the beginning of the song or sequence at the very next incoming Timing Clock message.

Parameters

None

SRT_Continue
SRT_Continue()

System Real Time Continue command

When the SRT source device sends a Continue command, the receiving device is expected to continue playing from its current location upon the arrival of the next Timing Clock command.

Parameters

None

SRT_Stop
SRT_Stop()

System Real Time Stop command

A Stop command sent from the SRT source tells the receiving device to stop playing immediately.

(Note that the source device may continue sending Timing Clock messages after a Stop command has been sent.)

Parameters

None

SRT_ActiveSensing
SRT_ActiveSensing()

System Real Time Active Sensing command

Active Sensing is a connection check command that is sent by the SRT source device at an interval of 300ms.

The source device should only send Active Sensing when in an idle state where no other MIDI messages are being sent.

It is recommended that these messages are evaluated with a roughly 10% margin before judging the connection to be lost.

Parameters

None

SRT_SystemReset
SRT_SystemReset()

System Real Time System Reset command

According to the MIDI v1.0 specification, a device receiving a System Reset message should:

%break%

  • Set Omni On, Poly mode (if implemented)

  • Set Local On

  • Turn Voices Off

  • Reset all controllers

  • Set Song Position to 0

  • Stop playback

  • Clear Running Status

  • Reset the instrument to its power-up condition

Parameters

None
